meanings.definition: To scold someone more severely or loudly than they scold you.
meanings.sent1: She always tries to outscold her little brother when they argue.
meanings.sent2: The teacher had to outscold the noisy students to restore order in the classroom.
meanings.sent3: The parrot outscolded its owner, mimicking the scolding sounds perfectly.
meanings.sent4: Her anger outscolded any previous outburst, leaving everyone stunned.
meanings.sent5: The thunderstorm seemed to outscold the angry teacher, booming louder than her scolding.

meanings.sent1: He managed to outscold his mother, surprising everyone with his loud reprimand.
meanings.sent2: The strict principal always outscolds the teachers when it comes to disciplining students.
meanings.sent3: The cat outscolded the dog, meowing loudly to express its disapproval.
meanings.sent4: Her scolding outscolded the thunder, echoing through the house with its intensity.
meanings.sent5: The wind seemed to outscold the trees, rustling their leaves in a scolding manner.
